stem: The public health nurse is conducting a community seminar on liver health. Based on the documentation in the Social & Occupational History for four individuals, match each risk profile with the correct prevention and teaching priority.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 19-year-old male planning a trip to a rural area with limited access to clean water. 
Patient B: 42-year-old female healthcare worker in a dialysis unit; has multiple needle-stick risks. 
Patient C: 25-year-old male with history of intravenous drug use; shares equipment. 
Patient D: 32-year-old female preparing food in a local restaurant that recently had a sewage leak.

tabs.title: Social & Occupational History
tabs.content:
PatientPrimary Risk AreaEducation Goal
ATravel to endemic fecal-oral regionFood/Water safety
BBlood-borne exposurePPE Compliance
CShared needlesHarm reduction
DFecal-contaminated food sourceHand hygiene

tabs.title: Immunity Status
tabs.content:
Patient B: Anti-HBs Positive (Immune). 
Patient C: Anti-HCV Negative (Susceptible).

rows.text: Drinking only bottled water and eating thoroughly cooked foods
Using condoms and avoiding the sharing of razors and needles
Receiving a 2-dose vaccine series at 0 and 6 months
Receiving a 3-dose vaccine series at 0, 1, and 6 months

rationale.correct: Hepatitis A is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, so prevention focuses on hand hygiene and food/water safety (r1); its vaccine is a 2-dose series (r3). Hepatitis B and C are blood-borne, so prevention focuses on avoiding shared needles/fluids (r2). The Hepatitis B vaccine is a 3-dose series (r4).
clinicalPearls: Hepatitis A and E: Vowels (A/E) come from the Bowel.
Hepatitis B and C: B for Blood/Body fluids.
There is NO vaccine for Hepatitis C.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking Hepatitis C has a 3-dose vaccine like Hepatitis B.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Only Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B have FDA-approved vaccines. Hepatitis C has no preventative vaccine.
